docs.lead_paragraph: Natural childbirth, far from being the choice of ''control-freak parents,'' is really about a willingness to surrender control to the birth process itself. Birth is not just ''getting through'' the pain. Fortunately, there are steps women can take to prepare for labor and birth. Some are about physical conditioning, but most are about training the mind. Self-hypnosis is an effective means of pain relief that has no side effects for the baby. Since a large part of pain is fear, often the most effective way to create an atmosphere that helps to sweep the mother ''downstream by the force of a shorter, more intense labor'' is to include a professional labor assistant.
docs.abstract: Robyn Perry Coe letter on Margaret Talbot's October 31 article suggests self-hypnosis can be effective in controlling pain during childbirth

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Charles E. Knox was terminated from his job in middle management at Microsoft in 1995, he sued the company, accusing it of breaching his employment contract. He asked for not only the usual lost salary, but also the worth of his options. A court awarded him $650,000 but denied him the value of any options. But last year, a Washington state appeals court agreed with Mr. Knox's larger claim, ruling that he was entitled to more than just the salary he had left behind. It said Mr. Knox, who had spent more than 10 years at Microsoft, could also claim the value of the stock options he lost when he left. His lawyers contend that those options are worth tens of millions of dollars, an estimate Microsoft disputes.

headline.main: More Fired Workers Are Suing for Stock Options

docs.abstract: Article on rising number of fired American workers who are filing suits against their old companies in order to reclaim lost stock options; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago I was an unwilling participant in natural childbirth. Two attempts at an epidural had failed, and finally it was too late to administer any anesthesia at all. My doctor told me that I was going to have to endure drug-free childbirth.
docs.abstract: Raleigh Mayer letter on Margaret Talbot's October 31 article disputes contention that intervention during childbirth is unnecessary

docs.lead_paragraph: Missing Out On the Calories ''I'm glad I don't work like this every week,'' the mezzo-soprano ANNE SOFIE VON OTTER said yesterday. She had had one of those if-it's-Tuesday-this-must-be-someplace-different itineraries: Boston on Sunday, New York on Tuesday and Toronto on Wednesday for a concert with the early music ensemble Musica Antiqua Koln. Did all the jetting around come at a price? ''Something went wrong in the first piece'' in Toronto, she said. ''It wasn't too bad. They kept on playing.''
docs.abstract: Public Lives column; mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie Von Otter discusses her family; author Stephen E Ambrose discusses giving $1.25 million to advocacy group American Rivers; Cherie Blair, wife of British Prime Min Tony Blair, is pregnant; designer David Rockwell discusses bidding on chair at charity auction at New York Design Center; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I never paid much attention to the information I gave when placing orders over the phone (''Do You Know Who's Watching You? Do You Care?'' Nov. 11), or even thought about what information the Department of Motor Vehicles, the telephone company or even my medical insurers might be giving out to other organizations. Until two years ago.
docs.abstract: Barbaranne M Warner letter on November 11 article on protecting personal information; recalls receiving numerous coupons and catalogs just days after her daughter was stillborn

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is no news at Freeport High School this fall. It is not that nothing is going on. On the contrary: The new principal has banned 10th graders from leaving campus for lunch. The teachers are working without a contract. And the girls' soccer squad went 6-6 after years without winning a game.

headline.main: High School Students Learn About Freedom of the Press

docs.abstract: Jodi Wilgoren, in Lessons column, notes that student editors of Freeport High School newspaper Flashings are on strike over firing of longtime adviser Ira J Schildkraut; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: KATHERINE CAMACHO CARR, Ph.D., nurse-midwife and educator, is the classic entrepreneur. She is driven by an unalloyed belief in her Internet-age vision of midwifery education and her dedication to women's health. She is kept afloat by buoyant optimism. Meanwhile, she cobbles together a living on the periphery of the mainstream, confident that the ideas she and her colleagues have been developing will one day make converts of the skeptics. Like many of this country's social innovators, Dr. Carr, 50, largely depends on grants from the public and private sectors. And given her bona fides, she certainly looks like Grade A grant bait.

headline.main: Walking a Tightrope From Grant to Grant to Grant

docs.lead_paragraph: JUST a few years ago, Cory Booker seemed to face a stark choice: he could aim to own the world or save it. An all-American high school football player from Bergen County, Stanford graduate and Rhodes scholar, Mr. Booker was not wanting for lucrative opportunities when he left Yale Law School. Instead he moved to a lousy building here on Martin Luther King Boulevard, which, if you believe Chris Rock, makes it the worst street in the city.

headline.main: Our Towns; Newcomer Gets Attention In Newark

docs.abstract: Matthew Purdy column on Newark Councilman Cory Booker notes that he will help lead two-day march to draw attention to plight of city's children, who have among highest rates of infant mortality, teenage pregnancy and failure to finish high school in nation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a Darwinian law of nature that adults believe everything was better when they were young: music, books, movies, clothes, bagels and, of course, young people. But once in a while, adults are humbled. Something comes along that they look at wistfully, or maybe petulantly, and say: ''Hey! Where was that when I was a teenager?''

headline.main: A Sex Guide for Girls, Minus Homilies

docs.abstract: New wave of books and computer Web sites are aimed at adolescent girls, on ever-daunting topic of being a girl; these are sources where girls can learn about their bodies, minus medicalese and pious homilies; one book, Deal With It! A Whole New Approach to Your Body, Brain and Life as a Girl, offers adolescent girls brash, nonjudgmental picture of changes they are going through; photo (M)
